statement.tex: \\ %text Which of the following assertions is correct? %

\\ %text \textbf{Check the calculations} Given the value of $\sin^{-1}\left( -\frac{1}{2}\right)$, has \[ \sin \left[ \frac\pi{3} - \sin^{-1}\left(-\frac{1}{2} \right) \right]\] been calculated correctly below? %

reason.tex:
%text There are \underline\text{infinite} angles $(\phi)$ for which \[ \qquad \qquad \sin\phi = a, \, a \in [-1,1] \]
But when we say \[\sin^{-1} a = \phi \], we have only one of those infinite angles in mind.
Which one? The one that lies in the principal range and is called the \underline\text{principal angle}.
For sine, that range is $\left[ -\frac\pi{2},\frac\pi{2}\right]$. Hence, \[ \sin^{-1}\left(-\frac{1}{2} \right) \in \left[ -\frac\pi{2},\frac\pi{2} \right] \]
And as $\sin\left( -\frac\pi{6}\right) = -\frac{1}{2}$ and $-\frac\pi{6}\in\left[ -\frac\pi{2},\frac\pi{2}\right]$, so \[ \qquad \quad \underline{\sin^{-1}\left( -\frac{1}{2}\right) = -\frac\pi{6}} \] %
